Award.AwardTitle: STEM Teacher Pathways Capacity Building Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Lewis & Clark Noyce STEM Teacher Pathways Capacity Building Project focuses the strengths of four Portland-area institutions on the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program's mission to encourage talented science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors to become K-12 STEM teachers. Robust degree programs aimed at producing well-prepared teachers in STEM fields are a national priority that underpin progress in science, the advancement of national health initiatives, and overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy. Furthermore, recruiting and preparing a diverse workforce of K-12 teachers to teach science and math to an increasingly diverse group of students is crucial to improving STEM education while encouraging and supporting more women and students from underrepresented minority groups (URM) to pursue majors and careers in the sciences. As has been observed nationally, community colleges provide an increasingly important entry point to STEM careers. Developing a STEM teacher recruitment, preparation, and induction model with collaboration between an undergraduate liberal arts college, a graduate school of education, a local community college, and a large urban school district is an important step in addressing the national shortage of well-prepared STEM teachers, particularly those that come from groups currently underrepresented in STEM fields. The model ensures that future STEM teachers have the content knowledge and pedagogical skills needed to succeed in today's diverse classrooms using a combination of scholarship support, rigorous academic courses and lab-based STEM research opportunities, meaningful and supported early classroom experiences, and mentoring at all points of their preparation and early careers as teachers.

The project is a partnership between Lewis & Clark College's College of Arts and Sciences (LC CAS), and Graduate School of Education and Counseling (LC GSEC), Portland Community College (PCC), and Portland Public Schools (PPS) and aims to build the framework for a STEM Teacher Pathways Program and design a scholarship model that will eventually engage four to five additional STEM preservice teachers per year in the LC GSEC Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) program. At the conclusion of this Capacity Building project, a plan will have been developed for the recruitment, preparation, and induction of a more diverse cohort of STEM teachers. Key features of the plan include: an articulation agreement that allows for the seamless transfer of credits from PCC to LC CAS; the availability of scholarships for PCC transfer students as well as other STEM teacher candidates; opportunities for LC CAS undergraduate students to conduct research with STEM faculty, and to be mentored by LC GSEC STEM teacher candidates; and an induction and mentoring plan designed to support new STEM teachers once they begin teaching. These features create a pathway that will increase the number and diversity of candidates who complete an MAT in STEM Teacher Education and are hired and retained as teachers in local and other schools. This program will draw from students majoring in Biology, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, Environmental Studies, Mathematics, and Physics. Ultimately, this program should lead to increased recruitment and retention of STEM teachers from diverse backgrounds, increased success for their students, and, ideally, a society of scientific literacy for all.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Lewis & Clark STEM Teacher Pathways Capacity Building Project built a foundation over two years to address the national shortage of well-prepared middle and high school Science Technology Engineering & Math (STEM) teachers. The project was a collaboration among an undergraduate liberal arts college, a graduate school of education, a local community college, and a large urban school district. Faculty and staff from the Lewis & Clark College of Arts and Sciences (CAS) and Graduate School of Education and Counseling (GSEC) worked together with personnel from Portland Community College (PCC) and Portland Public Schools (PPS) to build an innovative model that can be used by other similar partners to support the recruitment, preparation, and retention of a more diverse population of STEM teachers. 

Grant activities resulted in enhanced working relationships between PCC and Lewis & Clark’s College of Arts and Sciences at the administrative, faculty, and staff levels. To raise Lewis & Clark’s profile in the minds of prospective PCC transfer students, the PI and co-PI’s established a lunchtime speaker series at the PCC STEM Center, located at the southeast Portland PCC campus. Seven LC faculty presented lunchtime talks introducing their research,  highlighting LC undergraduate contributions to their work, and including a short overview of the Master of Arts in Teaching program. A total of 170 people attended the talks, including PCC students (the majority), faculty, and administrators. A survey given at the end of each talk showed that the talks were effective in increasing student interest both in transferring to Lewis & Clark and in a teaching career. 

Co-PIs worked in partnership with LC CAS department chairs, the admissions officer who works most closely with transfer applicants, and the registrar’s office to develop a one-page flyer outlining PCC math and natural sciences courses that are equivalent to courses required in the first two years of Lewis & Clark’s STEM majors. The flyer was shared with PCC’s transfer advisors, the LC CAS admissions office, and the LC College Advising Center and posted on the websites for both schools. The PI and co-PIs also brought together personnel from PCC and LC who are involved in the City of Portland’s Future Connect program, which provides support and scholarships for low income and first generation community college students. Lewis & Clark has partnered with the Future Connect program since 2013 under an agreement in which LC promises to meet the full demonstrated need of up to five Future Connect PCC students per year. As a result of this work, the memorandum of understanding between the two schools was updated, and enrollment of PCC transfer students using the Future Connect award at Lewis & Clark has been steady over the two-year grant period.

  The project team assessed the current needs of transfer students by conducting a focus group including students who had transferred to Lewis & Clark from community colleges and from other four-year schools. This discussion generated numerous suggestions for improving the experience of transfer students more broadly at LC. Suggestions were shared at CAS with the Admissions Office, the Dean of Student Life, the College Advising Center, faculty and staff attending a pedagogy lunch discussion, and at PCC with the Transfer Advising Office.

Efforts were made to recruit undergraduate STEM majors to careers in teaching, including presentations at STEM department seminars and evening panel discussions featuring recent LC grads pursuing teaching careers. The PI and co-PIs advertised education courses available to LC CAS undergraduate students via information tables and outreach to faculty and staff advisors. Enrollment in these courses was at or near capacity with a total of nearly 160 students enrolled over the two-year grant period. The class of 12 MAT candidates who began their program in June 2019 includes three STEM graduates of Lewis & Clark’s College of Arts and Sciences.

The two MAT STEM cohorts enrolled during the grant period benefited from a spring workshop about “Launching your career as a teacher.” The workshop was open to all Secondary MAT candidates, 18 of whom were planning a career in STEM teaching.

The collaborative development of a teacher recruitment, preparation, and induction model is an important step in addressing the shortage of well-prepared STEM teachers. The model developed through this project ensures that future STEM teachers have the content knowledge and pedagogical skills needed to succeed in today’s diverse classrooms using a combination of scholarship support, rigorous academic courses and lab-based STEM research opportunities, meaningful and supported early classroom experiences, and mentoring at all points of their preparation and early careers as teachers. The project provided insight into recruitment and retention strategies for STEM teachers, as well as the kinds of mentoring and support needed to ensure these future teachers can meet the needs of their students while remaining in teaching.
